case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 932 to 934 of 1968 and Civil Appeals Nos. 1439 to 1441 of 1968

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 932 to 934 of 1968 were filed from the judgment and order dated September 6, 1963 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 361, 430 and 706 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 6, 1963 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 361, 430 and 706 of 1963 and Civil Appeals Nos. 1439 to 1441 of 1968.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1439 to 1441 of 1968 were filed from the judgment and order dated April 26, 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 1792, 1818 and 1819 of 1968 and Writ Petitions Nos. 164 and 166 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 26, 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 1792, 1818 and 1819 of 1968 and Writ Petitions Nos. 164 and 166 of 1968. Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of the Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Appellants and writ petitioners carry on transport business in Andhra Pradesh under stage carriage permits granted under Motor Vehicles Act 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants and the writ petitioners carry on transport business in the State of Andhra Pradesh tinder stage carriage permits granted by the Transport authorities under the Motor Vehicles Act IV of 1939.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Taxation Act V of 1963 received assent of President on February 2, 1963 and came into force on March 20, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Taxation Act  Act V of 1963  came into force on the 20th March of that year after receiving the assent of the President on February 2, 1963. This is the Act number in force.

facts.text: Notification G.O.Ms. No. 601 Home Transport II Department dated March 27, 1963 imposed tax of Rs. 60 per seat per quarter on vehicles running less than 100 miles per day and Rs. 67.50 on higher mileage.

anchor.surface_text: On March 27, 1963 a numberification No. G.O.M. 601 was issued by the State Government in its Transport Department imposing a tax of Rs. 60 per seat per quarter on vehicles running less than 100 miles per day and Rs. 67-50 on vehicles companyering a higher mileage.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petitions by common judgment dated September 6, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: A crop t of writ petitions was filed before the High Court in the year 1963 ... By a companymon judgment and order dated September 6, 1963 the High Court dismissed all the writ petitions.

facts.text: Previous Validating Act of 1961 raised rate to Rs. 37.50 per seat per quarter effective April 1, 1962, upheld by Supreme Court in Nazeeria Motor Service case.

anchor.surface_text: The latest legislation ... was Validating Act of 1961 raising the rate to Rs. 37-50 per seat per quarter per bus effective from April 1, 1962. The Court upheld the impost.

facts.text: Notification No. G.O.Ms. No. 435 Home Transport II Department dated March 28, 1968 imposed higher taxes on buses based on mileage.

anchor.surface_text: In the second group of appeals Nos. 1439-1441/68 and in the two writ petitions the impugned numberification is numbered as O.Ms. No. 435 Home  Transport 11  Department dated March 28, 1968.

facts.text: On March 22, 1968, Government amended First Schedule by notification No. 434 increasing maximum quarterly tax to Rs. 121 for buses within municipal limits and Rs. 135 for others.

anchor.surface_text: On March 22, 1968 the Government of Andhra Pradesh purported to amend the First Schedule to the Act by ,notification No. 434 by increasing the maximum quarterly tax in respect of subitems  iii  and  iv  of item 4 to Rs. 121 in respect of buses Plying exclusively within municipal limits and to Rs. 135 in the case of other buses.

facts.text: High Court dismissed second group of writ petitions by judgment dated April 26, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: By a companymon judgment and order dated April 26, 1968 the High Court rejected the companytentions raised and dismissed this group of writ petitions.

facts.text: High Court found that revenue from taxes not exceed Rs. 6 crores while expenditure exceed Rs. 8,54,00,000 for 1963-64.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found itself unable to accept the above submission and on a scrutiny of the budget estimates for the year 1963-64, the receipts under the Taxation Act, the amount companylected by way of taxes on the sale of motor spirits allocable to this head, came to the companyclusion that the whole revenue would number exceed Rs. 6 crores while the expenditure incurred would exceed Rs. 8,54,00,000.

facts.text: Petitioners claimed taxes levied more for general revenue than compensatory for road facilities.

anchor.surface_text: An attempt was made, on behalf of the petitioners by reference to certain figures regarding the income of the State from this source of tax and the expenditure pertaining to this topic that the taxes were levied more for purposes of general revenue of the State than as a benefit for the facilities afforded to the operators of transport vehicles

facts.text: Road Transport Taxation Enquiry Committee report published November 1967 showed surplus revenue over road expenditure in Andhra Pradesh 1964-67.

anchor.surface_text: MrGupte however tried to draw a picture different from the above in the second set of appeals. I referred us to a report of an Enquiry Committee styled the Road Transport Taxation Enquiry Committee companystituted by the Government of India published in November 1967

facts.text: For 1967-68 budget, receipts from motor vehicle taxes estimated Rs. 9,55,53,396 while expenditure Rs. 9,81,65,411.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court went into this question in some detail and found that as per the budget estimates of 1967-68 the yield under the said head taxes on motor vehicles under the Motor Vehicles Act, receipts under the Provincial Motor Vehicles Taxation Act and other receipts was estimated to add up to Rs. 9,55,53,396/while the details of the expenditure under the several heads was of the order of Rs. 9,81,65,411/-

facts.text: Tax on spare buses at Rs. 30 per seat per quarter, required for operators with more than certain number of buses.

anchor.surface_text: A challenge was made to the additional impost on spare buses which bus operators running more than a certain number of buses per day were obliged to reserve for use in the event of any break-down. It was asserted that even for these buses, numbermatter whether they were actually used or number, tax was levied at the rate of Rs. 30 per seat per quarter.

facts.text: Every owner having five buses required to maintain one spare bus, more than ten buses two spare buses.

anchor.surface_text: Every owner having five buses is required to maintain one spare bus and operators having more than ten buses are to keep two such buses available.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Nazeeria case held Validating Act 1961 constitutional, reasonable and in public interest.

anchor.surface_text: In Nazeeria Motor Service case 1  the central question was the companystitutionality of the Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles  Taxation of Passengers and Goods  Amendment and Validation Act XXXIV of 1961. ... The Court therefore addressed itself to the question whether the restrictions imposed were reasonable and in public interest within the meaning of Art. 304 b .

facts.text: Government permitted increase in fares simultaneously with tax increase.

anchor.surface_text: It also took the view that the increase in the fares sanctioned simultaneously with the raising of the taxes had proved beneficial to the operators.

facts.text: High Court for 1968-69 budget found receipts would fall short of expenditure by about Rs. 50 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the budgetary figures for 1968-69 the aggregate of the items including works on repairs and maintenance expenditure on States Highways, road development fund works, capital outlay on roads works came to Rs. 8,75,87,900/- and taking into account the figures on the receipt side in the budget estimates, the companyrt was of the view that the total receipts would fall short of the anticipated expenditure by about Rs. 50 lakhs.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed all appeals and writ petitions with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals and the writ petitions fail and are dismissed with companyts.
Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of the Fundamental Rights.
All these appeals and Writ Petitions are directed against the Andhra Pradesh Motor Vehicles Taxation Act V of 1963 and notifications issued thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: figures regarding the income of the State from this source of tax and the expenditure pertaining to this topic that the taxes were levied more for purposes of general revenue of the State than as a benefit for the facilities afforded to the operators of transport vehicles, since the taxes were far in excess of the requirements for the construction of new roads and bridges and the maintenance of existing ones.

issues.text: whether the taxes interfere with the freedom of trade and commerce under Art. 301

anchor.surface_text: the object of the Act being only to raise the money required to afford facilities to the operators of the transport vehicles, the tax levied answered the description of compensatory tax and did not interfere with the freedom of trade and commerce. As such the taxes were held not to offend Art. 301 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the impugned Act had survived the test laid down by Art. 304(b)

anchor.surface_text: In the opinion of the High Court, the increase in the taxes was more than offset by the sanc- tioned increase in the fares and the grievance of the operators that the taxes were an unreasonable restriction was negatived. Finally the High Court held that the- impugned Act had survived the test laid down by Art. 304 b of the Constitution and had not transgressed the limits of reasonableness.

issues.text: whether the restriction imposed by the tax was reasonable and permissible having regard to Art. 19(1)(g) read with cl. 6 and Art. 301

anchor.surface_text: In the first set of appeals now before us learned counsel for the appellants submitted that in view of the, earlier decision of this Court the only question left for consideration was whether the restriction imposed by the tax was reasonable and permissible having regard to Art. 19(1)(g) read with cl. 6 and Art. 301.

issues.text: whether prior sanction of the President as required under Art. 304(b) was obtained

anchor.surface_text: The points of law raised by this set of writ petitioners before the High Court were a that prior sanction of the President as required under Art. 304 b was not obtained in respect of the levy inasmuch as such sanction was given in February and the levy was made towards the end of March. As such it was said G.O.M. 435 was unconstitutional and void.

issues.text: whether the proposed increase in the rate of tax was not in public interest but only a revenue yielding measure violating Part III and Part XIII

anchor.surface_text: b the proposed increase in the rate of tax was not in public interest but only a revenue yielding measure. Since it did not comply with the provisions of Part III and Part XIII of the Constitution it was illegal and unconstitutional. and c the levy of tax on spare buses was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court went into this question in some detail and found that as per the budget estimates of 1967-68 the yield under the said head taxes on motor vehicles under the Motor Vehicles Act, receipts under the Provincial Motor Vehicles Taxation Act and

court_response_anchor.surface_text: was also said that in the reply dated 12-1-1966 by the, State Government the estimated figure for the companystruction of roads was Rs. 2,49,45,200/-

holdings.text: There is no case of distinction so far as the first group of appeals is concerned from the decision of this Court in Nazeeria Motor Service case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Chart of taxes shows insignificant increase; follows Nazeeria precedent; accepts budget figures showing shortfall.

holdings.text: The facts and figures disclosed do not justify us in coming to the conclusion that the levy was a general one for augmenting the revenues of the State. On the other hand the figures disclosed show that the total receipts from the tax even now fall short of the expenditure on roads and allied purposes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Budget estimates and state affidavit reject committee report; receipts less than expenditure confirms compensatory nature.

holdings.text: We see no reason to take a view different from the above.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Reciprocal inter-state arrangements compensate for mileage-based tax on total distance including out-of-state.

holdings.text: we see no reason to hold that because of this the levy is unjustified, or ceases to be a compensatory tax.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Spare buses kept for use taxable under s.3; essential for maintaining service without interruption.

holdings.text: We are also not satisfied on the material before us that the impost has resulted in bus operators running their business at a loss.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of loss; prior fare increases and permit competition indicate profitability.

holdings.text: the appeals and the writ petitions fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals and the writ petitions fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges rejected; Act and notifications upheld as constitutional compensatory taxes.
